title: Docker Fundamentals
description: Basic concepts and getting started with Docker

questions.question: What is Docker?
questions.explanation: Docker is an open-source platform for developing, shipping, and running applications in containers.

questions.question: What is a Docker container?
questions.explanation: A container is a lightweight, standalone executable package that includes everything needed to run an application.

questions.question: What is a Docker image?
questions.explanation: A Docker image is a read-only template used to create containers.

questions.question: What is Docker Hub?
questions.explanation: Docker Hub is a cloud-based registry service for sharing and managing Docker images.

questions.question: What is the difference between a container and a virtual machine?
options: Containers share the host OS, VMs have their own OS
questions.correct_answer: Containers share the host OS, VMs have their own OS
questions.explanation: Containers share the host operating system kernel, while virtual machines include a full operating system.

questions.question: How do you check if Docker is installed?
questions.explanation: Any of these commands can be used to check Docker installation and version.

questions.question: What is Docker Desktop?
questions.explanation: Docker Desktop provides a GUI for managing Docker on Windows and macOS.

questions.question: What is the Docker daemon?
options: The background service that manages containers
questions.correct_answer: The background service that manages containers
questions.explanation: The Docker daemon (dockerd) is the persistent process that manages Docker containers.

questions.question: What is Docker Compose?
options: A tool for defining and running multi-container applications
questions.correct_answer: A tool for defining and running multi-container applications
questions.explanation: Docker Compose allows you to define and run multi-container Docker applications.

questions.question: How do you start the Docker daemon on Linux?
questions.explanation: On modern Linux systems with systemd, Docker is started using systemctl.

title: Working with Docker Images
description: Creating, managing, and using Docker images

questions.question: How do you pull an image from Docker Hub?
questions.explanation: docker pull downloads an image from a registry to your local machine.

questions.question: How do you list Docker images?
questions.explanation: docker images lists all images available locally.

questions.question: What is a Dockerfile?
options: A text file with instructions to build an image
questions.correct_answer: A text file with instructions to build an image
questions.explanation: A Dockerfile contains instructions for building a Docker image.

questions.question: What does the FROM instruction do in a Dockerfile?
questions.explanation: FROM specifies the base image that the new image will be built upon.

questions.question: How do you build a Docker image?
questions.explanation: docker build creates an image from a Dockerfile, -t tags it with a name.

questions.question: How do you run a container from an image?
questions.explanation: docker run creates and starts a container from an image.

questions.question: How do you list running containers?
questions.explanation: docker ps lists all running containers.

questions.question: How do you stop a running container?
questions.explanation: docker stop gracefully stops a running container.

questions.question: What is the difference between docker stop and docker kill?
options: stop sends SIGTERM, kill sends SIGKILL
stop is for images, kill is for containers
stop removes containers, kill keeps them
questions.correct_answer: stop sends SIGTERM, kill sends SIGKILL
questions.explanation: docker stop sends SIGTERM for graceful shutdown, docker kill sends SIGKILL for immediate termination.

questions.question: How do you remove a container?
questions.explanation: docker rm removes one or more containers.

questions.question: What is the default Docker network driver?
questions.explanation: The bridge driver creates a private network between containers on the same host.

questions.question: What is port mapping in Docker?
options: Mapping container ports to host ports
Mapping host ports to container ports
questions.correct_answer: Mapping container ports to host ports
questions.explanation: Port mapping allows external access to services running inside containers.

questions.question: How do you expose ports in docker run?
questions.explanation: The -p flag maps host ports to container ports.

questions.question: What is the host network mode?
options: Containers use the host's network stack
Containers get their own IP addresses
questions.correct_answer: Containers use the host's network stack
questions.explanation: In host mode, containers use the host's network directly without isolation.

questions.question: How do you connect containers to a custom network?
questions.explanation: docker network connect connects a container to a network.

questions.question: What is a Docker volume?
options: A way to persist data generated by containers
questions.correct_answer: A way to persist data generated by containers
questions.explanation: Volumes provide persistent storage that survives container restarts and removals.

questions.question: How do you create a named volume?
questions.explanation: docker volume create creates a new named volume.

questions.question: How do you mount a volume in docker run?
questions.explanation: The -v flag mounts a volume to a path inside the container.

questions.question: What is a bind mount?
options: Mounting a host directory into a container
Mounting a volume to a container
Mounting a container to another container
questions.correct_answer: Mounting a host directory into a container
questions.explanation: Bind mounts mount existing host directories into containers.

questions.question: How do you list Docker volumes?
questions.explanation: docker volume ls lists all volumes.

questions.question: What is a docker-compose.yml file?
options: A YAML file defining multi-container applications
A configuration file for single containers
questions.correct_answer: A YAML file defining multi-container applications
questions.explanation: docker-compose.yml defines services, networks, and volumes for multi-container apps.

questions.question: How do you start services with Docker Compose?
questions.explanation: docker-compose up builds, (re)creates, and starts containers.

questions.question: What is the services section in docker-compose.yml?
options: Defines the containers to be created
questions.correct_answer: Defines the containers to be created
questions.explanation: The services section defines each container and its configuration.

questions.question: How do you stop Docker Compose services?
questions.explanation: docker-compose down stops and removes containers, networks, and volumes.

questions.question: What is the depends_on option?
questions.explanation: depends_on defines the order in which services should be started.

title: Docker Best Practices
description: Best practices for Docker development and production

questions.question: Why should you use .dockerignore?
options: To exclude files from the build context
questions.correct_answer: To exclude files from the build context
questions.explanation: .dockerignore prevents unnecessary files from being sent to the Docker daemon during builds.

questions.question: What is a multi-stage build?
options: Using multiple FROM statements to optimize image size
questions.correct_answer: Using multiple FROM statements to optimize image size
questions.explanation: Multi-stage builds allow copying artifacts from intermediate images to final images.

questions.question: Why should you avoid running containers as root?
questions.explanation: Running as root can pose security risks if the container is compromised.

questions.question: What is the purpose of HEALTHCHECK?
options: To check if a container is healthy
questions.correct_answer: To check if a container is healthy
questions.explanation: HEALTHCHECK defines a command to check the health of a container.

questions.question: Why should you use specific image tags?
questions.explanation: Specific tags prevent unexpected changes when images are updated.

questions.question: What is Docker Content Trust?
options: A feature for verifying image integrity
questions.correct_answer: A feature for verifying image integrity
questions.explanation: Docker Content Trust uses digital signatures to verify image authenticity.

questions.question: What is a security scan in Docker?
questions.explanation: Security scanning identifies known security vulnerabilities in images.

questions.question: Why should you use non-root users in containers?
options: To limit the damage if compromised
questions.correct_answer: To limit the damage if compromised
questions.explanation: Non-root users follow the principle of least privilege.

questions.question: What is the --read-only flag?
questions.explanation: The --read-only flag prevents writes to the container's filesystem.

questions.question: What is the principle of least privilege?
questions.explanation: Least privilege means giving users/containers only the permissions they need.

questions.question: What is container orchestration?
questions.explanation: Orchestration tools manage container lifecycle, scaling, and networking across clusters.

questions.question: What is Kubernetes?
questions.explanation: Kubernetes is an open-source platform for automating container operations.

questions.question: What is Docker Swarm?
options: Docker's native clustering and orchestration tool
questions.correct_answer: Docker's native clustering and orchestration tool
questions.explanation: Docker Swarm provides clustering and orchestration capabilities for Docker.

questions.question: What is a reverse proxy?
options: A server that forwards requests to appropriate services
questions.correct_answer: A server that forwards requests to appropriate services
questions.explanation: Reverse proxies route incoming requests to the appropriate backend services.

questions.question: What is container monitoring?
questions.explanation: Container monitoring tracks metrics like CPU, memory, and application health.
